description: From Middle English frantike, frentik, variant of frenetik, from Old French frenetique, from Late Latin phreneticus, alteration of phreniticus, from φρενιτικός (phrenitikós, “mad, suffering from inflammation of the brain”), from φρενῖτις (phrenîtis, “inflammation of the brain”), from φρήν (phrḗn, “the brain”). Doublet of frenetic.

adjectives.description: frantic (comparative more frantic, superlative most frantic)

entries.meaning: In a state of panic, worry, frenzy or rush.
examples: They returned the missing child to his frantic mother.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A person who is insane or mentally unstable, madman.
examples: How nowe fellowe Franticke, what all a mort? Doth this sadnes become thy madnes?
